description: Start at the top of the midline and review the airways.
Look at the top and trace an imaginary line from the trachea to carina and the bronchus sources.
Evaluate if there is narrowing or dilatation of the bronchi.
reference: Dr Jeremy Jones et al.  Chest x-ray: ABCDE (summary). radiopaedia.org

title: B
label: BREATHING - RESPIRAÇÃO
phrase: (THE LUNGS AND PLEURAL SPACES / PULMÕES E ESPAÇOS PLEURAIS)

description: Look for pulmonary and pleural pathology.
Both lungs should be well expanded and similar in volume. Can you count 10 posterior ribs bilaterally? Is one lung bigger than the other?
Compare the apical, upper, middle and lower zones, are they symmetrical?
Are there areas of increased density (Consolidations?).
Trace the lateral margins of the lung to the costophrenic and cardiophrenic sinuses. Are the costophrenic angles clear?
Trace the heart edges that make contact with the lungs. Can you clearly see the limit of the left and right heart?
reference: Dr Jeremy Jones et al.  Chest x-ray: ABCDE (summary). radiopaedia.org

description: Look at the heart and vessels (systemic and pulmonary).
Check heart position.
Evaluate cardiac size (cardiothoracic index <50%).
Check the position and size of the aortic arch (Prominent aorta? Ectasiated? Aneurysmal?).
Check the width of the upper mediastinum (Masses? Aneurysm?)
Look at the hilar vessels (pulmonary hypertension?) Can you see them clearly on both sides?
reference: Dr Jeremy Jones et al.  Chest x-ray: ABCDE (summary). radiopaedia.org

title: D
label: DISABILITY - INCAPACIDADES
phrase: (BONES - ESPECIALLY FRACTURES / AVALIAÇÃO DE OSSOS E FRATURAS)

image.subtitle: Count of posterior costal arches in normal chest.
Costal arches fractures to the left.

description: Check for any bony pathology (fracture or metastasis).
Trace along each posterior (horizontal) rib on one side of the chest. Is there a fracture or abnormal area?
Repeat with the other size of the chest now trace lateral and anterior ribs on the first side.

Repeat on the other side now, check the clavicles and shoulders.
  • Can you trace around the cortex of the bones?

Finally the check the vertebral bodies.
  • Are they all rectangular and of a similar height?
  • Can you see 2 pedicles per vertebral body? Are there disc spaces?
reference: Dr Jeremy Jones et al.  Chest x-ray: ABCDE (summary). radiopaedia.org

description: Everything else including the upper abdomen and soft tissues.
Is there free gas under the diaphragms?
Is there a hiatus hernia?
Is there an absent breast shadow?
reference: Dr Jeremy Jones et al.  Chest x-ray: ABCDE (summary). radiopaedia.org
